poem:
Lost in the Halls  

In the care home's whispers,  
Lear wanders, crownless—  
echoes of a kingdom  
crumble in the quiet,  
daughters as shadows  
across linoleum shores.  
Madness weaves threads  
through his mind's tapestry,  
dementia's delicate touch—  
each memory a fleeting  
ghost—power lost  
yet alive in the bones  
of forgotten rooms.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. Shakespeare’s King Lear, for example, remains open to interpretation. Its story of a retiring king bequeathing his lands to his daughters before descending into madness can, in the right hands, engage with many themes in the modern day including dementia. It was not really necessary for writer-director Dan". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
